title: Robert Downey Jr. details spat with Hollywood exec in Howard Stern's green room
text:
Even A-lister Robert Downey Jr. can't escape the 'status games' in Los Angeles.

The Academy Award-nominated actor, 54, opened up about a dispute he was involved in with an unnamed show biz executive prior to appearing on The Howard Stern Show Monday from Sirius/XM's new Hollywood studio.

'I was just standing out there ... standing in front of the TV screen when this little nebbish big-wig says, "Out of the way!"'

The latest: Robert Downey Jr., 54, opened up about a dispute he was involved in with an unnamed show biz executive prior to appearing on The Howard Stern Show Monday from Sirius/XM's new Hollywood studio

The actor, who plays Iron Man/Tony Stark in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, told Stern that when he explained to the exec that the group was taking in the show, the executive replied, 'Who the f*** are you?'

The Tropic Thunder star said he nearly lost his temper - and thought he was 'going to have to light this guy up' - but cooler heads prevailed and things didn't get physical.

The Hollywood veteran said that individuals of 'certain status ... are the master of their environment' typically, and react as such when they cannot assert control over others. Stern joked that Downey is experienced with martial arts and 'could have killed' the exec.

Elsewhere in the interview, Downey gave his reaction to feted filmmaker Martin Scorsese's recent remarks that Marvel Films are 'not cinema' to Empire Magazine.

Upset: The Tropic Thunder star said he nearly lost his temper, but cooler heads prevailed and things didn't get physical

Unbothered: Downey shrugged off filmmaker Martin Scorsese's recent remarks Marvel Films are 'not cinema'

'Honestly, the closest I can think of them, as well made as they are, with actors doing the best they can under the circumstances, is theme parks,' the Oscar-winning filmmaker said. 'It isn’t the cinema of human beings trying to convey emotional, psychological experiences to another human being.'

Downey, noting that the franchise 'plays in theaters,' said he was glad to hear Scorsese's take.

'It's his opinion,' Downey said. 'I appreciate his opinion because I think it's like anything. We need all of the different perspectives so we can come to center and move on.'

La La Land: The iconic broadcaster delivered a show from the new SiriusXM Hollywood facility

Established: Stern's radio show began airing in LA in 1991 from its NYC headquarters

Stars: Stern also welcomed Jennifer Aniston, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Jimmy Kimmel and Adam Levine on his show Monday

Downey said that the MCU's success at the box office has been a game-changer in the industry: 'There's a lot to be said about how these genre movies - and I was happy to be a part of the "problem," if there is one - denigrated the art form of cinema.

'When you come in like a stomping beast and you eliminate competition in such a demonstrative way, it's phenomenal.'

The Sherlock Holmes star was one of a number of celebrities to visit Stern during his first West Coast broadcast in more than a decade, as Jennifer Aniston, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Jimmy Kimmel and Adam Levine also appeared on the program Monday.
